description: Within-section folio vocabulary outlier analysis: for each Currier B section, identify the most MIDDLE-vocabulary-divergent folio pair, then determine whether the divergence reflects different materials or different operational configurations.
methodology: Jaccard similarity on per-folio MIDDLE sets within each section. Divergent MIDDLEs classified by Levenshtein distance to nearest common MIDDLE (top-100 by frequency): distance<=1 = operational variant (per C939), distance=2 = moderate, distance>2 = independent. Candidate material discriminators require: independent status AND folio count >= 2 (or global count >= 5 if folio count = 1).
key_constraint: C939 (Tier 2): Zone-exclusive rare MIDDLEs are compositional elaborations of common MIDDLEs, not independent identifiers. 89.4% are edit-distance-1 from a common MIDDLE.
verdict_reason: No consistent material-discriminator patterns found across sections. All 38 independent MIDDLEs (distance>2 from any common MIDDLE) are hapax legomena (global count=1, folio count=1), meaning they are noise in the compositional tail, not recurring material identifiers. The 420 operational variants (91.7%) dominate divergence. Folio vocabulary differences within sections reflect different operational configurations (kernel profiles, regime emphasis, procedural phase selection) rather than different material identities. This is consistent with C939 (zone-exclusive MIDDLEs are compositional variants), C619 (unique MIDDLEs are behaviorally interchangeable), and the semantic ceiling (C120).
cross_section_pattern: The divergence mechanism is uniform across all 5 sections: high-frequency common MIDDLEs are present/absent in different combinations, and the long tail of rare MIDDLEs consists of single-character elaborations of those same common forms. No section shows a qualitatively different divergence pattern that would suggest material-specific vocabulary.

decoded_contrast.f76v_profile: 41 lines. E-kernel dominant with frequent KERN_HEAVY tokens. Interpretive: repeated 'cool' and 'cool-open' operations, interspersed with monitoring (shedy). Heavy use of 'qokeedy' (sustained heat) and discharge vocabulary (ed). Pattern suggests a settling/cooling-dominant procedure with interleaved heat checks.
decoded_contrast.f80v_profile: 44 lines. K-kernel dominant with heavy qok- prefix usage. Interpretive: intensive heat application (qokedy, qokaiin) with frame/control vocabulary (lsh, ct, lch). Multiple 'pound' (tch) and 'chop' (pch) operations. Pattern suggests a high-energy processing procedure with mechanical manipulation.
decoded_contrast.operational_difference: f76v emphasizes E-kernel (discharge, settling, cooling) while f80v emphasizes K-kernel (heat application, locking, frame operations). This is a regime difference (SETTLING vs HIGH_ENERGY), not a material difference.

B.narrative: Section B divergence (f76v vs f80v, J=0.271) is driven entirely by operational regime selection. f76v is settling/discharge-heavy (ed x10, eet, eedy patterns) while f80v is heat/frame-heavy (ct x5, lsh x3, lch x2, kch x2). All 56+30 unique MIDDLEs are operational variants or distance-2 moderates. The 3 independent MIDDLEs in f76v are all hapax with global count 1. No material discriminator candidates survive the frequency filter.

decoded_contrast.f26r_profile: 10 lines only (small folio). Diverse vocabulary with FL state markers, contains 'odaiir' (glossed: raw material) on line 1 -- the only token in the entire manuscript with that specific MIDDLE. E-kernel settling vocabulary (eo x5, ecth x2). Interpretive: division, cooling, and monitoring cycles.
decoded_contrast.f31r_profile: 16 lines. Output-focused vocabulary (eol x7 = sustain output). Heavier qok- prefix usage. Interpretive: sustained heat application with output collection. Pattern suggests a different procedural phase (output extraction vs input processing).
decoded_contrast.operational_difference: f26r is input/setup-oriented (odaiir, raw material; eo, cool-open; diverse FL state markers) while f31r is output/production-oriented (eol, sustain output; qokedy, heat). This reflects positional difference in the processing sequence, not different materials.

f1_top_independents.assessment: Hapax. Compound of known atoms (of+se+od). Not a material identifier.
Hapax. Compound of known atoms (ap+ch+ed+y+f). Not a material identifier.

f2_top_independents.assessment: Hapax. Compound of known atoms (ep+a+keo). Not a material identifier.

notable_token.assessment: This is the most semantically interesting token in the divergent pairs. Glossed 'raw material' in the middle dictionary, it appears on f26r line 1 (header position). However, odaii is distance-2 from 'aii' (a common MIDDLE), and its unique occurrence (global count=1) means it cannot serve as a recurring material discriminator. It may simply be an elaborated form of the 'unseal/open' operation (aii) with the od- (collect) prefix.

H.narrative: Section H shows the lowest Jaccard (0.181) of any section, but this reflects the small folio sizes (f26r has only 10 lines). The 5 independent MIDDLEs are all hapax (global count=1) and decompose into known atomic MIDDLEs. The notable token 'odaiir' (glossed 'raw material') appears on f26r's header line but is a hapax that cannot be confirmed as a material marker. Divergence is driven by operational phase: f26r is input/settling-focused, f31r is output/heat-focused.

decoded_contrast.f114r_profile: 45 lines. Large folio with extensive E-kernel settling vocabulary (eo x13, eod x6, eeod x2). Heavy FL state marker usage (i x15 = stage:early). Many daiin/dair scaffold tokens. Interpretive: sustained discharge/settling operations with careful stage tracking. Multiple checkpoint operations.
decoded_contrast.f116r_profile: 50 lines. K-kernel dominant with heavy direct-heat vocabulary (ck x10, ckh x3, eck x3, eek x2). Control/transfer vocabulary (ct x6, te x3, et x3). Interpretive: intensive heat application with tight control loops. Frame-based processing with binding operations (an x3).
decoded_contrast.operational_difference: f114r is settling/discharge-dominant (E-kernel, stage tracking, gradual cooling) while f116r is high-energy/heat-dominant (K-kernel, direct heat, locking). This is the same regime bifurcation seen in section B, confirming a consistent operational -- not material -- divergence pattern.

S.f1_top_independents_note: 11 independent MIDDLEs in f114r, but all have global count=1 and folio count=1. Examples: opailo, sheodaiiin, opchaiiin, fdeechd, eodaiisa -- all are long compound forms built from known atoms.
S.f2_top_independents_note: 3 independent MIDDLEs in f116r, all hapax: osheek, yrsh, olfc.
S.narrative: Section S has the most independent MIDDLEs (14 total across the pair), but every single one is a hapax (global count=1). This is the compositional tail predicted by C939: long compound forms assembled from known operational atoms. f114r's 98 unique MIDDLEs look large but 68% are operational variants. The divergence is regime-driven: f114r = SETTLING (eo, eod, discharge), f116r = HIGH_ENERGY (ck, ckh, direct heat). Same operational bifurcation as all other sections.

decoded_contrast.f66r_profile: 34 lines. Mixed kernel with precision vocabulary (ek x8, keo x4). Heavy compound qokee- forms. Several OIL_MARKER tokens (choekchy). Uses 'x' (diagram) tokens. Interpretive: precision heat operations, likely diagram-accompanied procedure.
decoded_contrast.f85r1_profile: 35 lines. PRECISION-regime dominant (m x4 = stage:final, od x3 = collect, dai x4 = start/step). More scaffold tokens (daiin patterns). Heavy monitoring vocabulary (sh- prefix). Interpretive: carefully staged procedure with explicit final-stage markers and collection operations.
decoded_contrast.operational_difference: f66r emphasizes precision heat and OIL markers; f85r1 emphasizes staged collection and monitoring. Both folios have similar PRECISION regime affinity but differ in operational emphasis (heat vs collection). The oil markers in f66r are suffix/MIDDLE-based (per C884/F-BRU-020 framework), not independent MIDDLEs.

T.narrative: Section T has only 2 folios, making statistical comparison limited. The 5 independent MIDDLEs across both folios are all hapax. f66r's OIL_MARKER tokens (choekchy) are interesting but these are detected via MIDDLE substring patterns (kc, okch) per the existing framework, not novel vocabulary. Divergence is operational: f66r = precision heat, f85r1 = staged collection/monitoring.

decoded_contrast.f86v4_profile: 5 lines with very long lines (48, 44, 46, 46, 4 tokens). Settling/discharge vocabulary (eed x3, eod x2, dai x2). ANIMAL markers detected (opor, oepor). Interpretive: extended discharge/settling procedures with animal processing signatures.
decoded_contrast.f86v6_profile: 45 lines with standard-length lines (11-13 tokens). K-kernel heavy (kch x7, olk x3, ksh x2). Frame/control vocabulary (p x6 = pause, cth x2 = hazard). Interpretive: intensive heat processing with precision control and pausing cycles.
decoded_contrast.operational_difference: f86v4 is structurally anomalous (extremely long lines, only 5) and settling-oriented, while f86v6 has standard structure and is heat/control-oriented. The line-length asymmetry may reflect different record types within section C rather than material differences.

f1_top_independents.assessment: Hapax. Uninterpretable compound, possibly transcription artifact.
Hapax. Compound of od+sh+eo (collect+verify+cool-open). Operational compound.

C.narrative: Section C's divergent pair (f86v4 vs f86v6, J=0.260) is the most structurally distinct: f86v4 has only 5 very long lines (up to 48 tokens) while f86v6 has 45 normal-length lines. Despite ANIMAL markers detected in f86v4 (opor, oepor), these are suffix-based identifications per existing constraint C884, not novel MIDDLE vocabulary. All 11 independent MIDDLEs are hapax. Divergence reflects structural format difference and regime selection (SETTLING vs HIGH_ENERGY), consistent with all other sections.

synthesis.universal_divergence_pattern: Across all 5 sections, within-section folio vocabulary divergence follows the same mechanism: regime bifurcation (SETTLING/E-kernel vs HIGH_ENERGY/K-kernel). Every divergent pair shows one folio emphasizing discharge/cooling operations and the other emphasizing heat/control operations. This is operational variation within a shared grammar, not material-specific vocabulary.
synthesis.independent_middles_assessment: All 38 independent MIDDLEs (distance>2 from common) are hapax legomena (global count=1). They are long compound forms built from known atomic MIDDLEs (e.g., ofseod = of+se+od, apchedyf = ap+ch+ed+y+f). They represent the extreme compositional tail of the morphological system, exactly as predicted by C939.
synthesis.material_encoding_location: This test confirms C939 and C619: material identity is NOT encoded in MIDDLE vocabulary variation between folios. If material encoding exists in Currier B, it must reside elsewhere -- possibly in: (1) header-line structure (line 1 tokens), (2) suffix distributions (C884 animal suffixes), (3) paragraph-level kernel profiles (C884 precision-animal correspondence), or (4) AZC-mediated constraints inherited from Currier A.
